title: Sources
text:
The clinical data used in this project was obtained from the Genomic Data Commons (GDC), a comprehensive platform managed by the National Cancer Institute (NCI) that provides open access to cancer genomics datasets. Specifically, the dataset focused on Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) and includes survival outcomes, treatment responses, and demographic information. This publicly available data supports transparent and reproducible cancer research.
GDC Data Portal: https://portal.gdc.cancer.gov

title: About
text:
Hi! I’m Darakhshan Fatima, and I love science and oncology. I chose to explore survival analysis as part of my journey into understanding complex biological and clinical data particularly in the context of cancer research.

title: Survival Analysis of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) Patients by Treatment Outcome
text:
Since we’re predicting a binary outcome (Survival_Status), a logistic regression model is appropriate.
Let’s define the model mathematically: \[
\text{logit}(P(Y = 1)) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{Age} + \beta_2 \cdot \text{Gender} + \beta_3 \cdot \text{CancerType} + \beta_4 \cdot \text{Stage} + \beta_5 \cdot \text{DiagnosisTime}
\]
Where:

( Y = 1 ) if the patient is Deceased, ( Y = 0 ) otherwise

logit(p) is the log-odds function: log(p/1-p)

Age is a continuous numerical variable

Gender, Cancer_Type, and Stage_at_Diagnosis are categorical variables, internally converted to dummy variables by R

Diagnosis_Date represents the date of diagnosis, which may need to be transformed into a numeric format (e.g., years since 2010)
